Award.AwardTitle: Electron Microscopy of Pulsed Laser Induced Rapid Solidification and Transient Solid State Phenomena in Nano-Scale Metal and Alloy Thin Films
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY: This project is an investigation of rapid solidification processes in pure metal and Al-rich Al(Cu) thin films. The main technique is in-situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) using the dynamic TEM (DTEM) at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) for ultrafast electron diffraction (UED) and imaging. There are no other measurement techniques currently capable of observing rapid solidification processes with interfacial velocities ranging from about 0.1 to 100 m/s in metal thin films with the required nano-scale spatial and temporal resolution offered by the DTEM. The research will reveal quantitative dynamic details of the extremely rapid liquid-solid transformation and other transient phenomena (e.g. solid-solid transitions) associated with Al and Al-rich Al(Cu) thin films and other FCC, BCC and HCP metals after single-shot pulsed laser melting. Robust modeling software codes, validated by direct comparison with quantitative measurements from in-situ DTEM experiments on pure metals, will be developed for the pulsed-laser melting. Post-mortem and in-situ microstructural characterization will be used to investigate microstructural evolution and defect formation in the solid state following solidification of pure metals with different crystal structures. The study of Al-rich Al(Cu) thin films is expected to help identify the conditions of morphological destabilization of the growth interface as function of pulsed laser power, alloy composition and heat-extraction parameters for hypo-eutectic, eutectic and hypereutectic compositions between Al and Al2Cu. The data obtained on parameters that determine the stability or instability of the transformation front will enable validation of theoretical solidification models. Apart from delivering basic scientific knowledge on metals under the extreme conditions of laser-induced rapid solidification, state-of-the-art experimental techniques for in-situ TEM will be developed for the purpose of probing the behavior of material volumes at time scales close to those accessible by computational modeling.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY: Solidification is a ubiquitous and fundamental process in materials fabrication, especially for metals, which are critical to energy generation and transmission, transportation and information technologies. Under extreme conditions of laser processing the growth dynamics determine the final microstructure and consequently performance-related properties in engineered components and devices. Understanding such phenomena is scientifically interesting and technologically important. The results of this research will be disseminated by peer-reviewed publications and presentations. The project involves outreach to high school students, via the Pennsylvania Junior Academy of Science and the development of semester-long research experiences for students enrolled in the new Pittsburgh Science & Technology Academy (grades 6-12). Students will receive training in vacuum and laser science, physical metallurgy, thin film science, micro-fabrication methods, scattering and diffraction physics, transmission and scanning electron microscopy, crystallography, thermodynamics, transport phenomena and numerical methods for materials modeling. Visits to, and continuous interaction with, LLNL will provide professional preparation outside the academic environment and access to state-of-the-art instrumentation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:  Developing understanding of the relationships between processing conditions, the associated microstructure formation and resultant properties is a fundamental challenge of the discipline of materials science. Solidification processes are ubiquitous in materials fabrication and for most technologically important metals and alloys involve the formation of multi-phase microstructures by irreversible transitions under conditions that deviate considerably from equilibrium. For large undercoolings and high cooling rates, rapid solidification entails and kinetic factors can become dominant over thermodynamic factors in determining the final material microstructures. Since thermodynamics provides only global, general features of solidification microstructures direct in situ observations are required to elucidate effects of the kinetics and reaction pathways selected during microstructure formation. The extremely fast transformation interface velocities (~0.1-100m/s) and fine scale (usually sub-micron to nanometer-scale) of important microstructural features of the evolving solid imply the need for experimental methods offering unprecedented ns- and nm-scale spatio-temporal resolution, which has previously prevented in situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) studies of metallic alloy rapid solidification microstructure formation. Here we exploited thin film specimen geometries, pulsed laser melting and utilized the unique combination of nano-scale spatio-temporal resolution offered by the dynamic transmission electron microscope (DTEM) at Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL) for ultrafast electron diffraction and imaging for in situ studies of rapid solidification transformations for the Al-Cu system in the range of compositions between Al and Al2Cu. In combination with post-mortem analyses of the rapid solidification microstructres this allowed for the first time in situ capturing of quantitative dynamic details of the extremely rapid solid-liquid-solid transformation sequences in multiphase alloys. The research delivered data sets that cannot be obtained with other experimentation, including quantitative measurement of local and global crystal growth rates based on direct observations of the moving transformation interface. Transformation front velocity changes, including an incubation period prior to onset of rapid solidification related crystal growth and accelerations in Al metal and hyper-eutectic Al-Cu alloys have been identified.  During the rapid solidification transformation sequence, the observation of morphological changes of the transformation interface and the determination of critical transformation rates associated with crystal growth mode transitions responsible for the formation of morphologically different microstructural constituents have been accomplished.

Broader Impacts: This project advanced the state-of-the-art of in situ TEM experimentation by developing robust experimental methodology and methods capable of previously unattaonable rapid solidification studies using pure metal and alloy specimen geometries. The experimental approach pioneered here is poised for application to a broader set of materials beyond the Al-Cu model system and has been shown to deliver data sets uniquely suitable to support computer model validation efforts related to rapid solidification transformations, which are relevant to many materials processing technologies, inclusive of melt-spinning, laser- and electron-beam joining, and selective laser melting based additive manufacturing. Research results have been emanated by publication in archival journals, conference proceedings and presentations. Two graduate students have received advanced research training, advanced degree education and professional preparation. Both graduate students have engaged in mentoring opportunities with unde...
